page.title: 09BURGH CASTLE CHURCH
page.content: The lovely church of St.Peter and St.Paul at Burgh Castle forms half of the 'living' for the rector, with the similiar building in Belton.Both have the round tower which is usually an indication that in former days the parish could not afford expensive imported materials.The base of the tower was built from flint and tiles taken from the nearby Roman fort.The gables show clearly that the roof was originally thatched.Inside several phases of construction may be seen,the most interesting of which is the now redundant staircase which once led to a rood gallery.The church dates back to 7th Century and was founded by the Irish missionary St.Fursey.A Celtic cross in the churchyard bares a gaelic inscription in his memory.
